abstract: Late last year George S. Cole of Elmhurst, Queens, was informed that the company where he had worked for 24 years was phasing out his division. At the age of 50, he faced the daunting prospect of trying to find another job.   "Very fortunately for me, and unlike so many others facing a similar situation, I did manage to find another position elsewhere in the company," he wrote in a recent letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "The fates have indeed been kind this year."
lead_paragraph: Late last year George S. Cole of Elmhurst, Queens, was informed that the company where he had worked for 24 years was phasing out his division. At the age of 50, he faced the daunting prospect of trying to find another job.

snippet: After his wife took her life, Jose Ventura brought his young sons to New York from the Dominican Republic. He provides for them while working as a building superintendent.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, Jose Ventura, 53, is unflappable. A building superintendent who presides over 86 apartments in Inwood, he fields calls from tenants day and night and battles for turf with gangs that sometimes leave their drugs and guns behind. Mr. Ventura also looks after his two young sons.

snippet: Alex Chan, 17, escaped an abusive father in their tin-roofed house in Central America and made his way to Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A tumbledown home with a tin roof high in the mountains of Guatemala had no electricity or beds, only tattered clothing and rationed food. At breakfast, Alex Chan and his three siblings shared a single egg, split into quarters. At night, they went to bed hungry as they waited in fear of their father.

headline.main: When Fire Takes All but the Memories
headline.print_headline: When Fire Takes All but the Memories

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund

abstract: Maggie Lee, a 60-year-old Harlem resident, spends her days as an aide to an 86-year-old woman who lives in Washington Heights. When she gets home, she looks after four grandchildren and her husband, who had his left leg amputated below the knee because of diabetes.    This was not the sort of hectic schedule that Ms. Lee had envisioned for herself as she neared retirement age. But in  November 1992 Ms. Lee learned that her daughter, Patricia, had been shot and killed after an argument. That the argument was over a broken freezer, and that the man who shot her daughter was the building superintendent, added to the meaninglessness of the death.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Lee, a 60-year-old Harlem resident, spends her days as an aide to an 86-year-old woman who lives in Washington Heights. When she gets home, she looks after four grandchildren and her husband, who had his left leg amputated below the knee because of diabetes.

lead_paragraph: They were the precious fittings of Magdalena Cepeda’s hard-won life: books for school; tenderly arranged jeans and shoes; DVDs and a computer; photos of her children, growing older from one frame to the next.

snippet: Irina Shevchenko left Ukraine with her young daughter, setting up a household in Brooklyn while waiting for her husband to join them. With little at the outset, she needed a bit of help after a setback.
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the old Julian calendar, the Russian Orthodox Church celebrates Christmas on Jan. 7. So on Christmas Eve, about three weeks ago, the reunited Shevchenko family  who immigrated from Ukraine to Albany in 2007  had reason to celebrate the relief and security of a new, clean and bedbug-free apartment in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

abstract: A couple with almost nothing took a risk, moved to Brooklyn and got a little help to start over.
snippet: A couple with almost nothing took a risk, moved to Brooklyn and got a little help to start over.
lead_paragraph: Sixty years later, he still remembers the smell of burning bodies somewhere near him. It was a 24-hour-a-day stench, unrelenting and inescapable. It hung, still, in the air at night. It greeted him when he woke up in the morning: an invisible, pervasive reminder of the living nightmare of Nazi control. Yosef Ostrowicz, born in Poland in 1928, survived the war, going into hiding in 1943 after he escaped the Warsaw Ghetto. But his parents and older sister did not survive. Separated from the three boys in the family, they were ushered off to their eventual deaths as Mr. Ostrowicz and his two brothers watched.

headline.main: Long After Escaping the Holocaust, Need for a Little Help to Adjust in Brooklyn
headline.print_headline: Long After Escaping Holocaust, the Need for a Little Help to Adjust in Brooklyn

abstract: Lydia Monserrate’s mother tried to keep her away from a bad crowd by putting her in foster care, which brought more trouble until a caseworker found her an apartment.
snippet: Lydia Monserrate’s mother tried to keep her away from a bad crowd by putting her in foster care, which brought more trouble until a caseworker found her an apartment.
lead_paragraph: Lydia Monserrate lived in 13 foster homes in the past five years. But she is not an orphan.

abstract: A Manhattan family was already struggling with financial problems when the unthinkable happened: their 17-year-old son was shot to death.
snippet: A Manhattan family was already struggling with financial problems when the unthinkable happened: their 17-year-old son was shot to death.
lead_paragraph: To enter the apartment of Kendrick Moore and Carol Bowman-Moore in the Alphabet City neighborhood in Lower Manhattan is to be greeted by a ghost. Not far from the doorway is a table adorned with dozens of photos that preserve Shytik Bowman, killed last year, as he will always be remembered: a charismatic young man a few weeks shy of 18 with more than a passing resemblance to the singer Chris Brown.

headline.main: Struggling to Go On After a Son’s Death
headline.print_headline: Struggling to Go On After a Son’s Death

abstract: Drugs made John Cox feel numb to the struggles he endured growing up gay. Now he has embraced the doctrine of Narcotics Anonymous.
snippet: Drugs made John Cox feel numb to the struggles he endured growing up gay. Now he has embraced the doctrine of Narcotics Anonymous.
lead_paragraph: As a child, John Cox, 44, did not like getting dirty; he did not like to roughhouse; he did not like a lot of the activities that other boys seemed to love.

headline.main: Misery Did Not Work, but Vanity Saved Him
headline.print_headline: Misery Did Not Work, But Vanity Saved Him

abstract: A man with Duchenne muscular dystrophy has difficulty maneuvering his wheelchair in his new home. His old one was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy and is uninhabitable.
snippet: A man with Duchenne muscular dystrophy has difficulty maneuvering his wheelchair in his new home. His old one was badly damaged by Hurricane Sandy and is uninhabitable.
lead_paragraph: Facing a life wrought with trials, Jason Celik is also a virtual prisoner in his home.
